SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mrs. Minnie Taphein

Present Address: St. Gregor, Sask.

Pioneer Address: St. Gregor, Sask.

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1926 Nov. 18

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Six homes, were family homes. How many of these were bachelor's homes? We had fairly bachelor neighbors.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Generally once a week.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? When such we wished.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? It was done without invitations.

What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Sometimes in afternoon, sometimes evenings.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, we stayed as we were told to.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) They said you better stay for supper.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Coffee, bread and butter, sometimes cake and fruit.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Sometimes we all went, sometimes not.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, we had a bee for building a log barn.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

The neighbors came early, everyone brought hammer and saw. Our big log barn was built, beginning of April 1907.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There were no whist drives. Only in town once in awhile, no dances. But we had parties when plenty young folks were there.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Yes, there were more frequent in later years.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? We went when we felt like having a good chat with a neighbor, sometimes once a week. Sometimes once a month.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many times were near enough to visit back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes? Our family had friendly neighbors.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Occasionally once a week.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Whichever we wished.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? It was done without invitation.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? We came home after work, sometimes even at dinner time.

5. Did you ever have a meal when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "to make potluck" used or was some other expression common?)

6. Did you ever have a fire for building a log barn?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

8. Were there no social dances? Only in town once in awhile, no dances. But we had parties when plenty of young folks were there.

9. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

10. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by car, train, etc., once a month, etc.? We went when we felt like having a good chat with a neighbor, sometimes once a month.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc. if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

As long as I can remember, there was only one dance held in school. There were no box socials or Christmas concerts in the early years.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

I came to St. George in 1904 at the age of 17. I never went to a Catholic school although I spent four years of single life in the district before I married. Then I moved away and came back to this district in 1936.

9. When was your first community hall built? It was built in St. George. But I forgot when.

What material was it made of? Of lumber. How large was it? I do not know.

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? I think the community through special funds.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? It was built in the village.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?) I never went to these gatherings, as they were mostly in winter. It was too far at night, and too cold.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? No

How were babies and small children provided for? They were mostly kept at home.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? They were put in a barn and fed.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? The men generally played cards.

Was there card playing for a prize? There was in town.

What dances were popular? Square dancing, waltz, two step, rye waltz, one step, cakle two steps.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No everyone seemed to get along all right.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. It was up to the person if he wanted to play cards he could. If he did not want to play it was alright. Nothing was said if they did not want to play.

12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? There were no parlor around here. Whatever body sat in dining room, they wore hats. But not gloves and no, they did not use calling cards. But everyone was treated as best they could make it.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc. There were mostly in town. When they came and chivareed a couple, a drink was generally passed to each one. The bunch sometimes sang songs. There were no incidents.

They played games of deadman, and who's got the bottle, post office, auctioneer, fruit basket upset, Please and these games were played around 1908—displease.

22. What winter games were played outside? Fox and hounds, skating, etc.?

PIONICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.
   The first picnic took place at [illegible] in July, though from 1968.

26. Was it organized by?
   The Catholic Church held this picnic.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? It was for the church.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes, as much as no.
   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?
   Ball games, choir singing, and meeting friends.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?
   There was dinner served. Every family brought some eats, and they charged for the dinner.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?
   There was everything one could think of to eat; coffee was for drink and soft drinks.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
   It generally started at 10 till evening in morning till evening.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

I have a collection of Indian hammers, stamps, do shell work also have collection of shells and rocks. I started collecting rocks in the State of Wash., as there are so many beautiful rocks there. I have quite a few agates, a thunderhead, a geode, a barn rock and other started in 1947.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

Birds generally came middle April or end of April. Trees started greening middle May or late. Depended on weather.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

I would like if one could learn other hobbies. I also make seed pictures and have made a swing tree. In the States an extension teacher comes round once a month. They learn something different every time.
